discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
When an Elastic Load Balancer (ELB) HTTPS listener is configured without specifying a security policy, the ELB will automatically select the latest available version of the SSL/TLS policy that is supported by the ELB platform. This policy determines the protocols and encryption algorithms that will be used to negotiate the SSL/TLS connection between the client and the ELB.

It's important to note that the choice of security policy can affect the compatibility of clients connecting to the ELB. Different policies support different versions of SSL/TLS and encryption algorithms, and some older clients might not be compatible with the latest policies due to security vulnerabilities.

While the ELB can select a default policy, it's generally recommended to review and select an appropriate security policy that meets your application's security and compatibility requirements.

questions.question_text:
A user has configured an HTTPS listener on an ELB. The user has not configured any security policy which can help to negotiate SSL between the client and ELB.
What will ELB do in this scenario?
questions.answer_description: Elastic Load Balancing uses a Secure Socket Layer (SSL. negotiation configuration which is known as a Security Policy. It is used to negotiate the SSL connections between a client and the load balancer. If the user has created an HTTPS/SSL listener without associating any security policy, Elastic Load Balancing will, by default, associate the latest version of the ELBSecurityPolicy-YYYY-MM with the load balancer.

AWS CloudWatch is a regional service, which means that each CloudWatch instance operates independently within its own AWS region. In the scenario described, the user has EC2 instances running in two separate regions and is sending data to CloudWatch in US East (North Virginia) region.

Even though CloudWatch instances in different regions operate independently, data sent to CloudWatch using the same namespace and metric name will be aggregated by CloudWatch when retrieved from the AWS Management Console, CLI, or APIs. This means that CloudWatch will provide an overall view of the aggregated data for the specified namespace and metric, regardless of the region from which the data originated.

Therefore, option B is the correct choice. CloudWatch will receive and aggregate the data based on the namespace and metric, providing a unified view of the metric across different regions.
B. CloudWatch will receive and aggregate the data based on the namespace and metric

questions.question_text:
A user has two EC2 instances running in two separate regions. The user is running an internal memory management tool, which captures the data and sends it to
CloudWatch in US East, using a CLI with the same namespace and metric. Which of the below mentioned options is true with respect to the above statement?

choices.B: CloudWatch will receive and aggregate the data based on the namespace and metric
choices.D: CloudWatch will take the data of the server, which sends the data first
choices.C: CloudWatch will give an error since the data will conflict due to two sources
choices.A: The setup will not work as CloudWatch cannot receive data across regions

questions.answer_description: Amazon CloudWatch does not differentiate the source of a metric when receiving custom data. If the user is publishing a metric with the same namespace and dimensions from different sources, CloudWatch will treat them as a single metric. If the data is coming with the same timezone within a minute, CloudWatch will aggregate the data. It treats these as a single metric, allowing the user to get the statistics, such as minimum, maximum, average, and the sum of all across all servers.
